title: Profiling adaptation and its place in climate change debates with TwitterÂ (II)

sections.html: A first broad exploration of the network graph shows a number of aspects that have long been a subject of discussion in the climate debate among scientists and the public. The network displays clusters focused on the two main approaches to dealing with the impacts of climate change, which are adaptation and mitigation. The visualization further reveals a number of dense clusters and some smaller more dispersed clusters. The particularly dense clusters reflect a localized take on the issue of climate change, centered on political events. Different metrics of vulnerability also find their way as important topics in the network, including international clusters, driven by instances of extreme weather as well as intergovernmental climate change conferences and similar events.
sections.title: How to read the map

sections.html: Using the Twitter Capture and Analysis Toolset (TCAT), developed by the Digital Methods Initiative at the University of Amsterdam (Rieder & Borra, 2014), a dataset of tweets between 23 November 2012 and 23 November 2013 containing the query [climate change or global warming] was obtained, consisting of 4,771,135 tweets from 1,780,225 distinct users. We identified hashtag clusters in the climate change Twitter space through a co-hashtag network analysis performed in Gephi using the modularity class algorithm and OpenOrd layout, and further manually annotated the clusters along with a close reading of the actual tweets to verify the different themes. The result is an annotated map of clusters which shows the top issues in the climate change space on Twitter.
